IX General principles of quantum mechanics

We now have all the tools to formulate the general principles of quantum mechanics, which we state in terms of four postulates.

IX.1 Quantum states

Postulate I: All experimentally accessible information about a quantum system is contained in a state vector |ÏˆâŸ©.

Remarks: An example is the wave function Ïˆâ¢(x) of a point particle in one dimension. In three dimensions a point particle is described by a wave function Ïˆâ¢(x,y,z). We will also discuss the state of two particles with position ğ«ğŸ and ğ«ğŸ, which is described by a wave function Ïˆâ¢(ğ«ğŸ,ğ«ğŸ). Furthermore, we encounter the spin of an electron, which is described by a two-component vector Ïˆ=(Ïˆâ†‘Ïˆâ†“).

IX.2 Observables and operators

Postulate II: Each experimentally observable quantity A^ is represented by a hermitian linear operator.

Remarks: Here, the term observable refers to any measurable quantity. Examples are position x^=x, momentum p^=-iâ¢â„â¢ddâ¢x, energy H^=p^2/2â¢m+Vâ¢(x), but also kinetic energy T^=p^2/2â¢m and potential energy V^=Vâ¢(x) can serve as observables. Another example is the angular momentum ğ‹^=ğ«^Ã—ğ©^ in three-dimensional systems, where ğ«^=(x^,y^,z^) is a vector composed of the three position operators, and ğ©=(p^x,p^y,p^z) is a vector composed of the three momentum operators px=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡x, py=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡y, pz=-iâ¢â„â¢âˆ‚âˆ‚â¡z. Later we will also consider an analogous vector operator ğ’^=(S^x,S^y,S^z) representing the spin of an electron.

In the context of quantum mechanics, eigenvectors |anâŸ© of an observable A^ are also called eigenstates. The property of hermiticity ensures that all the eigenvalues an are real, while the eigenstates can be used to construct an orthonormal basis.

IX.3 Dynamics

Postulate III: The time evolution |Ïˆâ¢(t)âŸ© of a quantum state is governed by the SchrÃ¶dinger equation

iâ¢â„â¢ddâ¢tâ¢|Ïˆâ¢(t)âŸ©=H^â¢(t)â¢|Ïˆâ¢(t)âŸ©, (123)

where H^ is a system-specific hermitian operator called Hamiltonian.

Remarks: In the particular case H^=constâ¢(t) of a time-independent Hamiltonian, the eigenvalues of H^ are denoted as En, and are interpreted as energies of solutions |Ïˆâ¢(t)âŸ©=expâ¡(-iâ¢Enâ¢t/â„)â¢|nâŸ©. Here, the stationary states |nâŸ© fulfill the eigenvalue equation Enâ¢|nâŸ©=H^â¢|nâŸ©, which is known as the stationary SchrÃ¶dinger equation.

Given an initial state |Ïˆâ¢(t0)âŸ©, the general solution can always be written as |Ïˆâ¢(t)âŸ©=U^â¢(t,t0)â¢|Ïˆâ¢(t0)âŸ©, where U^â¢(t,t0) is a unitary operator called the time evolution operator. This operator fulfills the SchrÃ¶dinger equation iâ¢â„â¢ddâ¢tâ¢U^â¢(t,t0)=H^â¢(t)â¢U^â¢(t,t0) with initial condition U^â¢(t0,t0)=I^. For a time-independent Hamiltonian, the time evolution operator takes the explicit form

Using the eigenrepresentation H^=âˆ‘nEnâ¢|nâŸ©â¢âŸ¨n| of the Hamiltonian we can write U^â¢(t,t0)=âˆ‘nexpâ¡[-iâ¢(t-t0)â¢En/â„]â¢|nâŸ©â¢âŸ¨n|. We will examine time dependence in detail in later chapters.

IX.4 Measurements

The last postulate concerns the remarkable quantum effects which occur when one determines the value of an observable in an experiment. Since this is the most complicated postulate we break it down into three aspects.

IX.4.1 Experimentally observable values

Postulate IVa: In an experiment that determines the value a of an observable with associated operator A^, the only possible (allowed) observable values are the eigenvalues an of A^.

Remarks: E.g., when one measures the energy of a particle bound in a potential well, the only possible results are the discrete energies En determined by the stationary SchrÃ¶dinger equation. Because of the hermiticity constraint on such operators, these values are always real.

IX.4.2 Generalised wave function and probability

Postulate IVb: If the normalised state of the system at the time of the measurement is |ÏˆâŸ©, each outcome occurs with probability

Pâ¢(a)=âˆ‘an=a|âŸ¨n|ÏˆâŸ©|2=âˆ‘an=aâŸ¨Ïˆ|P^n|ÏˆâŸ©, (125)

where |nâŸ© is the eigenstate associated with an, and P^n=|nâŸ©â¢âŸ¨n| is the associated projection operator.

Remarks: Using the orthonormality of the eigenstates |nâŸ© and the normalisation condition âŸ¨Ïˆ|ÏˆâŸ©=1, it follows that the probability Pâ¢(a) is automatically normalised: âˆ‘aPâ¢(a)=1 if a is discrete, and âˆ«Pâ¢(a)â¢ğ‘‘a=1 if a is continuous.

Disregarding for the moment the possibility that eigenvalues are degenerate, it is useful to interpret the probability in terms of a generalised wave function

ÏˆAâ¢(an)=âŸ¨n|ÏˆâŸ©, (126)

which consists of the coefficients of the wave function in the eigenbasis of A^,

|ÏˆâŸ©=âˆ‘nÏˆAâ¢(an)â¢|nâŸ©. (127)

The probability Pâ¢(a) that an experiment returns the value A^=a is then given by

Pâ¢(a)=|ÏˆAâ¢(a)|2. (128)

In one dimension, the generalised wavefunction is given by the overlap integral

ÏˆAâ¢(an)=âˆ«Ïˆn*â¢(x)â¢Ïˆâ¢(x)â¢ğ‘‘x. (129)

An example is the momentum wave function Ïˆ~â¢(p), discussed in section VII.1, which is calculated with help of the momentum eigenfunction Ïˆpâ¢(x)=(2â¢Ï€â¢â„)-1/2â¢expâ¡(iâ¢pâ¢x/â„)â¢dâ¢x, and corresponds to a Fourier transformation. The factor (2â¢Ï€â¢â„)-1/2 provides that Pâ¢(p)=|Ïˆ~â¢(p)|2 is properly normalised.

IX.4.3 Effect of experiments on the system state

Postulate IVc: A measurement with outcome a transforms the quantum state into the state

|Ïˆâ€²âŸ©=1/Pâ¢(a)â¢âˆ‘an=aP^nâ¢|ÏˆâŸ©. (130)

Remarks: Using the decomposition (127) of the pre-measurement state |ÏˆâŸ© in the eigenbasis of the measured observable A^, the post-measurement state can be written as |Ïˆâ€²âŸ©=1/Pâ¢(a)â¢âˆ‘an=aÏˆAâ¢(an)â¢|nâŸ©. Thus, only the components of the eigenstates with eigenvalue compatible to the measured outcome a are retained, and the result is then normalised. It follows that |Ïˆâ€²âŸ© is an eigenstate of A^. In the case that the eigenvalues are not degenerate, a measurement with outcome an simply transforms the state of the system into the eigenstate |nâŸ©.
